title: Friday, 6th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

All the news is political

PM11:01am

Well most of it

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Have a funny video

PM11:02am

https://www.youtub...=122&v=9_kahrh-LW0

PM11:02am

Dunno why that's not rendering

11:02 am
PM11:02am

You just have to watch the first minute or so of that

PM11:03am

Saudi king having to walk down his personal escalator

PM11:03am

Bloomberg have the full boogling detail

11:03 am
PM11:03am

https://www.bloomb...ntourage-in-moscow

undefined
PM11:03am

To Markets

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Dow up pretty sharply overnight

PM11:03am

As Trump will tell you

PM11:04am

London -- less so

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Well, we're up a bit

BE11:04am

Well, we'd be quite sharply lower if it weren't for sterling getting tonked again.

PM11:04am

Yeah, was about to mention slight krona-ish trend

11:04 am
PM11:04am

1.3054 on my screen

BE11:05am

Which is on the back of ....... Grant Shapps of all things.

BE11:05am

Claiming he has 30 MPs backing his call for May to exit.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

It's not known if he's counting his alter-egos of Michael Green and Sebastian Fox there, so the number might yet change.

PM11:06am

Theresa definitely in trouble tho

PM11:06am

https://twitter.com/Telegraph/status/915974512923029504

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Full details here https://www.ft.com...-93c5-648314d2c72c

BE11:07am

Matt there, nailing it as usual.

PM11:07am

Is Shapps up to being the "ringleader"

11:07 am
BE11:07am

He can be a stalking horse for the ultimate stalking horse, plausibly. He's not a Redwood.

BE11:08am

Market consensus is still that May blunders on, though.

BE11:08am

And that we'll get that interest rate hike the BOE's been badgering us about.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

You'll note Ian McCafferty -- one of the BOE's two consistent hawks -- sounding quite pleased with himself overnight.

BE11:09am

"Brexit-related uncertainties effectively tie our hands until the UK has left the EU."

BE11:09am

And "the little slack that currently remains [in the economy] is likely to disappear quite quickly, while inflation is projected to persistently overshoot the target."

11:10 am
BE11:10am

All of which jars a bit with the OBR story about productivity disappearing, that was our splash overnight.

PM11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-93c5-648314d2c72c

PM11:11am

From Chris Giles

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Anyway, want some Deutsche strategists to add some pseudoscientific probabilities to political in-fighting? That's always useful.

PM11:11am

Sure

BE11:12am

Deutsche sees a 55% probability that May will continue, "because of the lack of obvious replacements".

11:11 am
BE11:12am

[T]he most likely outcome, in our view, is that the current leadership remains at least until the current stage of Brexit negotiations and the autumn Budget are concluded. This would mean Brexit talks continue under their current (more constructive) framework since May's Florence speech. The main risk is EU reluctance to negotiate based on (a fair or not) perception of impermanence about PM May. Assuming that this can be overcome, continuity in May's leadership should not have major implications for Brexit outcomes in the near term. In the medium term, however, yesterday's speech has much reduced the prospect of May continuing as Prime Minister to 2022.

BE11:12am

That leaves a 30% chance of an orderly transition, as per the 2003 unopposed election of Michael Howard.

BE11:12am

And that's mean a runoff between David Davis, Damian Green and Amber Rudd. (Hammond and Johnson would be too divisive to consider, Deutsche reckons.)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

In our view, it is unlikely either Davis, Green or Rudd deviate significantly from the existing Brexit negotiating framework due to lack of time and need for continuity. The appointment of Davis, however, could be seen as a modest positive given his ability to rally behind him the Eurosceptic elements of the Conservative Party behind a framework of compromise.

BE11:13am

... And only a 15% chance of a full leadership contest.

BE11:13am

Though DB's 15% probability seems to be based on the idea that it's the worst possible option so probably won't happen.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

As I say, there's questionable value in applying logic to politics. But that's what strategists, and by extension markets, have to do I guess.

BE11:13am

First, based on recent precedent, the contest would take around two months to conclude, putting on hold Brexit negotiations at a critical juncture (as well as other key announcements like the Budget next month). Second, to appeal to the Conservative Party membership, it is likely that the successful candidate fights on a hard Brexit platform, which could undermine market confidence. Third, the potential winner may be relatively unknown, given the experience of past elections. Fourth, the potentially divisive nature of a leadership contest would increase the likelihood of another general election.

PM11:14am

There's a hell of a lot of political risk in there. But markets really don't price this stuff in now

11:14 am
PM11:15am

We really could end up with Comrade Corbyn in power

BE11:16am

Nope, indeed, so it's not really bothering. We've seen it a thousand times that when a possibility is difficult to feed into Excel -- such as Korean war, or a tilt aggressively left for the government, or an actual lunatic being put in charge of the world's largest economy -- then investors just tend to ignore it and hope nothing much changes.

undefined
11:16 am
BE11:16am

But enough politics.

PM11:16am

So, to movers

PM11:17am

Must be some relief around Easyjet

11:16 am
PM11:17am

But still off 2.5%

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,265, down 19.04 (-1.48%), High: 1,280, Low: 1,244, Volume: 2.03m
PM11:17am

Trading update here https://www.invest...1710060700038828S/

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Yeah, guidance nudged up a tad .... but consensus had already gotten ahead of where EasyJet is right now.

BE11:18am

Perhaps they'd already priced in the McCall performance deflator.

BE11:18am

So, FY guidance goes from £380m-420m to £405m-410m.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Consensus was already £402m.

BE11:19am

Bad news for 2018 includes capacity guidance, which is 6%

BE11:20am

Consensus was at 8%.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

EasyJet talking positive unit momentum offset by continued yield pressure due to capacity growth.

BE11:21am

You'll remember the rally the sector had on Monarch failing, and Air Berlin failing, and Alitalia failing. The pricing power that lost capacity is providing isn't really coming through yet, it appears.

BE11:22am

Here's Panmure, who are sellers.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

FY17 is closing out in-line with market expectations and industry dynamics are supportive near-term. But we still harbour concerns over cashflow strains, which we feel are overlooked at present.

BE11:22am

FY17 PBT guidance narrowed to £405m-£410m, which is c.2% ahead of £400m consensus (PGe £395m) driven by Q4 (Jul-Sept) revenue per seat -3.7% (PGe -4%) making -1.4% for H2, versus -2% guidance. Capacity growth was 8% with record load factors of 95.6%. Ex-fuel unit costs +1% is in-line. The unit fuel bill tailwind of £230m-£235m is marginally softer than previous guide, whilst £100m adverse FX is in-line.

BE11:23am

(@RA: they'll restore capacity, you'd assume, but the benefit is questionable given how much the European short-haul industry resembles a classic prisoners' dilemma.)

11:23 am
BE11:23am

FY18 outlook is not quantified at this early stage. EZJ expects continued pressure on yields (PGe -1.2%) reflecting on-going market capacity growth which EZJ sees at 5% in Q1 (EZJ planning 6% itself). MT ex-fuel unit cost guide is +1% and unit fuel costs are expected to be £125m-£145m favourable, with a £20m FX headwind. We feel this is broadly consistent with current consensus for £472m PBT (PGe £452m is 4% below).

BE11:24am

Investment case. Our concerns over mediocre cost progress relative to LCC peers, ramping capex with dividend payments uncovered by FCF and ROCE under pressure have recently played second fiddle to potentially more positive short-term industry dynamics. EZJ has a strong core business but growth is harder to come by in its capacity-constrained hubs. However, Ryanair’s own goal (on flight cancellations, planned capacity reductions and customer PR) and Monarch’s administration (Gatwick/Luton route overlap with EZJ) make for a more benign near-term trading environment, with speculation that EZJ could be a beneficiary of Air Berlin/Alitalia carcases. At 14x FY18 PE and 8.3x EV/EBITDA (average debt) we struggle to justify the valuation premium to a historic average of 11.5x/6.2x respectively, given the above cash flow dynamics, CEO in limbo and uncertainty over UK/EU flying rights post- Brexit. Hence we remain at SELL.

BE11:25am

Seems EasyJet 2018 consensus is pretty wide, with some at the top expecting c.20% growth YoY

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Which ain't going to happen.

undefined
PM11:26am

Sheesh -- I hadn't seen Lonmin

11:26 am
PM11:27am

It's up 20%

PM11:27am

This is on having some debt waved?

PM11:27am

Covenant waiver

11:27 am
PM11:27am

https://www.invest...1710060700038780S/

BE11:27am

Yep. This is on banks approving the Pandora JV

Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 90.07, up 16.07 (+21.71%), High: 90.13, Low: 75.50, Volume: 4.84m
11:27 am
PM11:28am

Still do wonder about the broad picture in South Africa tho

PM11:28am

Morgan Stanley have a big thing out on SA today

PM11:28am

It's not very upbeat!

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Last week we hosted our 8th annual South Africa investor conference at the Vineyard Hotel in Cape Town. We were left in no doubt that the structural challenges facing the market remain significant.

PM11:28am

In this review, we summarise the feedback from the week's meetings and keynote presentations into three broad sections: (1) we consider the major macro topics that were up for discussion - fiscal concerns and the condition of state-owned enterprises (SOE) financing were key ; (2) we encapsulate micro issues into five sub-topics; (3) we provide a compendium of feedback notes from key company presentations.

PM11:29am

Takeaways...

11:28 am
PM11:29am

1) Fiscal: The degree of investor pessimism was notable. Consensus seems to be for a meaningful miss in tax revenues, a loss of the fiscal anchor, a deterioration in the debt metrics and an S&P downgrade this November.

2) Eskom: Participants' concerns were elevated, with an expectation that further government guarantees and/or equity support will be required.

3) Politics: It seems to be a three horse race for the presidency of the ANC this December. The political commentator we heard from believes that Mr Ramaphosa has the greatest chance of emerging victorious.

4) Beating the cycle: the macro economic environment may be tough but various JSE-listed companies are managing to outstrip the macro malaise, just as they have done in the past. In this report we discuss 12 companies that appear to be beating the cycle this time around and another 8 that may be losing ground against their peers.

5) Offshore vs onshore investing: Offshore diversification was a common theme again at the conference. We update the numbers on geographic exposure of the JSE and MSCI SA indices: 57% of the JSE SWIX All Share and 58% of MSCI SA is essentially exposed to non-South African assets.

PM11:29am

Ramaphosa would be relatively good news for SA, I think

PM11:29am

But I'm not sure that's going to happen in a smooth way

11:30 am
BE11:30am

...... in terms of Lonmin, I think its troubles can be seen as separated from politics right now.

BE11:31am

This deal is a short term salve.

BE11:31am

As in, lenders waive tangible net worth covenant test for September 2017 and March 2018

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Actually, rather than me muddle through it, here's RBC to explain the main points.

BE11:32am

Its banks have approved the Pandora JV acquisition from AngloPlat and Northam – this will allow Lonmin to defer ZAR2.6bn (US$190m) of capex, of which ZAR1.6bn (US$117m) would have been required in the next four years. The deal is expected to close in Q1/FY18E (December Q). In our view the deferral of capex allows Lonmin to further improve its near-term financial position despite challenging market fundamentals.
Its banks have also granted a waiver for its two Tangible Net Worth (TNW) covenants (Consolidated net debt not to exceed 35% of TNW, TNW no less than US$1.1bn) for the 30 September test date, and a pre-emptive waiver of its TNW covenants for the six month period to 31 March 2018, on the condition that LMT: (i) cancels its US$21m revolving B2 facilities; and (ii) leaves its remaining US$200m of RCFs undrawn until 31 March 2018.
Providing its lenders are satisfied with its business plan post-operational review and its perceived ability to meet its future covenant tests, the ~US$200m of RCFs will remain available.
Lonmin generated cash of US$14m in Q4, taking the H2 cash build to US$25m; net cash at year-end is ~US$100m, gross cash ~US$250m.
The company expects sales to come in slightly ahead of its 650-680koz Pt sales guidance (RBC: 637koz), with unit cost (ZAR11,300-ZAR11,800/oz) and capex (ZAR1.4bn-ZAR1.5bn) reiterated.

BE11:32am

In our view, the above points alleviate near-term pressure from the balance sheet and should see Lonmin’s financial position improve, assuming that prices and FX stay flat and the company does not experience operational disruption. Long term, we continue to view the company’s fundamentals as challenged given its labour-intensive mining methods which, in our view, will drive sustained cost and margin pressure (labour is ~50% of opex) given inflationary labour increases of ~8%/yr. That said, we think near-term relaxation of balance sheet pressure should see the shares move higher today. The shares are trading at 5.98x NAV, 2.6x FY18E CF and a 3% FCF yield for FY18E, pre-capex adjustments.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

So, it's a bet on stability as much as anything.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:33am

Centrica being mentioned on the right.

11:33 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 175.11, down 2.4 (-1.35%), High: 178.10, Low: 174.50, Volume: 22.63m
BE11:34am

Lowest since .......... 2009, I think?

PM11:35am

Worse than that -- 2003 prices actually

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Cripes. Was trying to work out the return since privatisation this morning, but it defeated me. Needed to price out the spinoff from BG, and also the shares in National Grid and Shell you would've had for signing up in the 1980s.

BE11:36am

And yep, you're right. Pre crisis levels.

BE11:36am

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So, we have Investec leaping in now and saying sell.

BE11:37am

It's on the price cap, or course.

BE11:37am

We view the Government’s forthcoming legislation enabling broad ‘price cap’ intervention as a sea change in a long drawn-out saga. While falling short of a direct instruction to Ofgem, a price cap affecting an additional 50% of the domestic market now seems most likely (again). We find the profit impact on suppliers is likely severe. The existing prepayment price cap cost allowances suggest the ‘Big 6’ are inefficient, by a wide margin in some instances. Even if the regulators reassess efficient cost benchmarks, we see broad regulation having considerable financial and industrial impact.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

That's a cap that's a sea change in a long drawn-out saga. Quite a metaphor.

BE11:37am

Still not certain, but the balance of risks has shifted: Ofgem is widely understood to favour limited price cap intervention affecting c. 10% of the market (possibly those 2.6m customers that receive the Warm Home Discount). The Draft Bill is expected to empower Ofgem to install a wider price cap covering 50% of the market on standard variable tariffs (SVTs). The Government RNS does not appear to be an instruction to that effect, but this may be forthcoming. We see an SVT price cap as the most likely eventual outcome. We have previously outlined our analysis on ‘waterbed effects’ (unintended price rises for uncapped customers), concluding the risk is greater for narrower price cap intervention.

BE11:38am

Prepayment cap sets a tough benchmark on efficiency: The existing price cap on prepayment meter customers implies an average price cap across the market of c. £961 p.a. per domestic customer, which is c. £170 below current ‘Big 6’ prices. The effective margin in the anticipated cap is £25 / 2.3% (vs 4.5% ‘Big 6’ margin in FY16/17A).

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Short term impacts more severe than medium term: In the short term, the financial impact reflects: a lower margin, indirect cost inefficiencies, and wholesale energy hedging strategies that are mismatched with the cost allowance in the cap. This last aspect is likely to be challenged by companies, potentially culminating in phased allowances for companies to adjust hedging strategies. In any case, in the medium term, we assume wholesale efficiencies/inefficiencies are not relevant.

BE11:39am

(@BornCynic: pro tip. Get a certified boiler engineer to have a look and tell you exactly the parts you need. Buy those parts online, and get either the same or a different boiler engineer to fit them.)

BE11:40am

(@BornCynic: the boiler folk all have agreements where they can only buy parts from certain suppliers which makes the process take ages and favours replacement over repair. But they're usually fine with shortcutting it, if offered that option.)

11:40 am
BE11:40am

[/Watchdog]

BE11:40am

SSE (Buy, TP 1475p from 1520p) is potentially protected from dividend cuts: SSE is relatively efficient on indirect costs per customer, which may allow it to earn a c. 3.0% margin in the medium term. Dividend cover is likely to move only just below the 1.2x – 1.4x target range, in our view, which does not yet imply aggressive cuts.

SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,371, down 9 (-0.65%), High: 1,386, Low: 1,368, Volume: 1.02m
11:40 am
undefined
PM11:41am

Renishaw a big faller in the 250

Renishaw PLC (RSW:LSE): Last: 4,445, down 435 (-8.91%), High: 4,804, Low: 4,410, Volume: 115.06k
11:41 am
PM11:41am

Who's doing the damage there?

PM11:41am

No news that I've seen

BE11:42am

Stifel. Sector note. Brexity.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

In which it decides that Renishaw's a bit expensive.

BE11:42am

Much like every other stock that can be mentioned in the same sentence as Apple.

BE11:43am

Here's the gist of it.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We admire Renishaw’s remarkable record of innovation, and creation of what is a de facto worldwide standard in its industrial metrology niches. Its end markets have picked up, and it is once more achieving double-digit organic growth rates. We believe, however, that the very strong performance of the stock has more than discounted these positives, and has left the shares looking overvalued both vs. its international peer group and in the context of our long run assumptions for the company itself. The gap between our assessment of fair value and the prevailing market price has become sufficiently wide that we are now downgrading our rating to Sell. We see few near-term negative catalysts, but note that the company operates with little visibility (and even less market communication) and has tended to be volatile: we think that after an extended period of very strong performance, holders should consider taking some profit.

BE11:44am

So, valuation.

BE11:44am

Valuation is at the heart of our concerns on the group at present. On our estimates, the stock trades at almost 32x this year’s forecast earnings, and 22.5x EBITDA. Using our June 2019 numbers, these multiples only come down to 28x and 20x, respectively – and this is despite the fact that our 2019 forecasts are well above consensus (177p of headline EPS vs. the Bloomberg consensus of 163p).
This is fairly unprecedented valuation territory for an industrial company, other than highly cyclical names ahead of an anticipated turn in end markets – and Renishaw’s markets have already turned, and its margins are already north of 20%: these are not high multiples of deeply depressed earnings.
Even more striking than the absolute numbers are the trends in relative performance and valuation over the last year. Renishaw is quite distinct from most of the UK industrial peer group – much higher- technology-focused, with far higher R&D investment, and current growth rates, which would be the envy of just about all of its peers - but it does have a small group of international peers who are much closer to it in terms of end market focus and market dynamics – and over the last year it has moved ahead of these peers fairly dramatically in terms of share price performance. Below, we show its share price performance (rebased) vs. its closest European peer, Hexagon (HEXAB.ST, SEK 406.1, Not Covered) in Sweden, and two US partial peers, Ametek (AME, $66.86, Buy; covered by our colleague Robert McCarthy) and National Instruments (NATI, $43.20, Buy; covered by our colleague Patrick Newton).
From the middle of 2016, Renishaw has run ahead of the pack by a wide margin. It is probably no coincidence that the start of this period coincides with the Brexit referendum and the slide in the value of sterling – a big boost that may now have run its course (while Brexit may yet bring much more negative repercussions for the group, dependent on the outcome of trade negotiations).

11:44 am
PM11:44am

That point about "market communication" is a fair one.

PM11:45am

Never really that much detail in their statements

PM11:46am

But this is a sizeable business now -- £3.6bn market cap

11:46 am
BE11:46am

They have a bunch of confidentially clauses I guess, at least in the electronics side of the business, as your metrology machines need to be bought quite early in a smartphone maker's roadmap or whatever.

BE11:47am

Anyway, here's the upshot of Stifel's thoughts on the sector.

BE11:47am

Economic data and leading indicators suggest improved and
relatively robust growth in the global industrial economy. We believe that this masks a sharp variation in fortunes between individual end markets however. Areas such as automation, metrology, and US onshore oil and gas are seeing strong trends; but power generation, other parts of oil and gas sector, and new build business in ‘heavy’ capex markets remain depressed, and in some cases even deteriorating.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Alongside this mixed demand picture, individual corporate fortunes are also influenced by some more strategic issues. In particular, M&A has had a major impact on share performance. Successful deal making has been central to the performance of Melrose, Smiths and to a lesser extent Spirax and Bodycote – while an absence of transactions has weighed on Halma. We expect acquisitions and disposals to remain significant to performance in the next 12 months; we see this providing a likely positive catalyst for Melrose, Smiths, Halma and Spectris in particular.

BE11:47am

Winners and losers: Spirax, Halma, Renishaw (and, in its own particular style, Melrose) have provided long term, accelerating sector outperformance – but this has left valuation differentials across the sector at record levels. While we see further upside potential in some of these names (Halma, Melrose) we focus rather more on the scope for Smiths and Spectris to rejoin this group of highly rated sector leaders, and also see attractive medium-term upside in laggards (and value situations) Morgan Advanced and Ricardo.

Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 220.10, up 6.1 (+2.85%), High: 220.90, Low: 214.40, Volume: 2.72m
11:48 am
undefined
PM11:48am

US Air Force air-to-air refueller declares an emergency over UK airspace

PM11:49am

Sounds a bit alarming

11:49 am
PM11:49am

No further details yet

BE11:49am

.... without further information or any knowledge of what that actually means, I'm choosing not to be alarmed.

BE11:49am

Though something to keep an eye on, certainly.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

So ......... what else is moving? Oh, here's an odd thing.

BE11:50am

We've been banging on all week about Anglo American, for various reasons .....

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,483, up 9 (+0.61%), High: 1,488, Low: 1,471, Volume: 1.60m
11:50 am
BE11:51am

This morning, apropos of nothing much, I checked the short interest.

BE11:51am

Which has done this:

BE11:51am

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Top graph is shares on loan as a percentage of free float.

PM11:51am

Blimey

BE11:52am

Now, I'm guessing the loan must be some kind of hedge of the mandatory convertible that Agarwal's using for his 20% stake thing. But that's a total guess, and I can't of my own volition figure out how that would work.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Ah, right. Interesting idea

BE11:53am

Quite eyecatching graph, though.

BE11:53am

In terms of other heavily shorted things ......

11:53 am
Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 218.17, up 6.37 (+3.01%), High: 221.70, Low: 211.50, Volume: 722.57k
BE11:54am

18% of free float out on loan there, Markit tells me.

BE11:54am

Which turbocharges HSBC "buy" advice.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Price investment strategy is working. Pets at Home began investing in prices earlier in 2017 to close the unsustainable price gap to aggressive online pure plays. Key lines have been reduced by 15-30%, and volume have responded well with an elasticity of c2.5x. This has driven a positive inflection in LFL growth. We expect management to make the most of improving momentum to continue to invest in the offer and drive further growth. Pets at Home now appears to be leveraging its competitive scale advantages far more effectively to the benefit of customers, which drives our more positive outlook for the Merchandise business. The improved visibility and sustainability of the Merchandise business should allow the focus to return to the significant growth opportunity on offer in Services.

BE11:54am

Services growth targets increased. At its recent CMD, Pets at Home increased its JV vet target to 1,000 sites from 700. We believe this is realistic in the context of over 5,000 vet sites in the UK, and we believe there could be further upside. We suggested that 1,500 may be realistic in our report Services a Hidden Gem of 10 October 2016. Maturity and roll out should drive substantial growth in JV fee income and EBITDA. We see the potential for fee income to double and EBITDA to roughly triple over the next 5 years and there should be more to come beyond that.

BE11:55am

The investment case is now getting back to where it should be, in our view, and this is positive. We believe that Pets at Home should be capable of delivering mid- to high-single digit profit growth each year for the next 15-plus years as it benefits from structural industry growth trends, competitive advantages and the consolidation of fragmented services niches. The traction that the price investment strategy has shown reassures us that this is achievable, which should increasingly marginalise concerns over the sustainability of the business model. Within this note, we look at the long-term potential of the business as it hits it growth ambitions and its estate matures.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Raise TP to 245p from 210p; retain Buy rating. Enhanced growth potential drives a higher valuation. Although the shares appear to enjoy a premium to the sector, trading on a CY18e PE of 15x vs the sector on 12x, we believe this fails to recognise the attractions of the Services business. Taking peer CVS Group as a proxy for Services implies that the Pets at Home Retail business is valued at just 2x at the current share price. At our target price, this would improve to a still very reasonable 6x.

BE11:56am

(@man from dunoon: at this exact moment, we've nothing to say there.)

undefined
11:56 am
PM11:56am

Look at this, in response to Chris Giles's tory..

PM11:56am

https://twitter.com/BenChu_/status/916242466621321217

PM11:57am

Treasury officials talk to newspapers, shock

11:57 am
PM11:57am

We have no idea who Chris spoke to btw

undefined
BE11:58am

(@Soundbuy: Yep, Micky Mouse-branded hip replacements. Fairly sure that's what I meant, IIRC.)

11:58 am
BE11:59am

... and sticking with sellside for a moment, since there's not much else .....

BE11:59am

...... Turkey Factory's up.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 278.30, up 7.2 (+2.66%), High: 278.50, Low: 270.60, Volume: 866.13k
11:59 am
BE11:59am

Caz is very excited about Peppa Pig going to China.

PM12:00pm

hmm

BE12:00pm

Yeah, really.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

As eOne’s recent trading statement has proven, the rollout of the Family operations (the Peppa Pig franchise but also increasingly PJ Masks / Ben & Holly) is performing particularly well in markets like the U.S. and China. In our detailed analysis, we have assessed the revenue potential of Family in the International markets and conclude that even the company’s guidance for doubling retail revenues between 2015 and 2020E appears too conservative – our base case ends up +30% higher. Overall, we believe Family alone is worth £830m or 190p (for eOne’s 85% stake, versus or previous valuation of £630m). In our blue-sky scenario, we see a valuation of £1.4bn or 310p for Family alone as possible.

BE12:00pm

Ben & Holly is very confusing for toddlers, can I note.

BE12:00pm

Because it uses all the same voice actors as Peppa Pig.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

So you end up having to explain why a pig is also a wizard.

BE12:01pm

Anyway.

BE12:01pm

As a producer of strong content assets (c.80% scripted), the
business benefits from significant price inflation in the space and
increasing monetization opportunities globally. We assessed the long-term revenue opportunity particularly for eOne’s Family business and see our base case for 2017-2020E revenue CAGR of +25% for Family as conservative. Reflecting higher estimates for the division, we have increased our 2018E/2019E/2020E EPS estimates by +2%+9%+14% and remain OW the shares with a Dec 2018 target price of 331p (Dec 2017 269p previously). We see a further 120p upside in our blue-sky scenario. The shares are trading on cal. 2017E/2018E P/E of 12.5x/10.4x.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

And there's fantasy M&A in there, of course.

BE12:01pm

... and we see further upside potential from M&A. eOne attracted a preliminary proposal from ITV last year, highlighting the value for other Media companies and possible M&A related upside. Recent transaction multiples for content players (DHX Media for Iconix Brand Group, holder of Peanuts at 11x EV/EBITDA) underline our bullish view.

BE12:02pm

Plus the lack of actual cash.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

We expect improving Equity FCF going forward. Rightly or wrongly, eOne’s ability to generate FCF remains a key focus. We expect the company to turn positive on that metric (£1m in 2018E).

BE12:02pm

So, that's that.
